attributes.action: Allow the hospitality sector to continue indoor dining whilst in Covid tier 3
attributes.background:
We are petitioning to allow all hospitality establishments including restaurants, pubs & cafes to serve food indoors & outdoors to single household tables within a Covid secure environment, whilst in tier 3.

We are not encouraging household mixing and therefore there is minimal infection risk.
attributes.additional_details:
The current tier 3 government restrictions are crippling the hospitality industry and it can no longer be sustained. 

In some areas of the UK, hospitality has only been allowed to open in some capacity for less than 50% of the time since March.

Theres no hard evidence to prove that a restaurant is a higher infection risk than a supermarket, nail salon, hairdressers, gym or mall, however these establishments are able to open within tier 3 and the hospitality sector are being unfairly penalised

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/561917

attributes.action: Ban Home Fireworks Except For Professional Organised Displays
attributes.background:
Ban fireworks at residential addresses.
Ban the sale of fireworks except to licensed and organised events.
Take fireworks out of shops and only available wholesale to licensed traders.
attributes.additional_details:
Fireworks Need Banning Except For Professional Organised Displays! 
So many animals suffer every year because of fireworks due to the loud noises. Animals suffer with all kinds of anxiety and stress. 
The emergency services also have their workload unnecessarily increased due to accidents and fires caused whether they’re genuine accidents or results from stupidity! I appreciate the children enjoy them but would they not have more enjoyment at an organised event with family and friends in a safe environment preferably away from all animals!

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

attributes.action: Allow UK driving instructors to work during the 2nd coronavirus lockdown
attributes.background: Our working environment is COVID-secure, as we are strictly PPEs compliants. Our training is educational and of vital importance for those whom are in need of a driving licence, in order to avoid using public transport.
attributes.additional_details:
During the 1st national lockdown, Britain’s 40,000 driving instructors had faced an immense mental & financial hardship, until they managed to resume training and effectively adopted to a new way of using PPEs whilst delivering driving lessons.
Moreover, a 2nd round of suspension of driving tuition would inevitably means that learners would also be fatigued and somewhat traumatised by this unnecessary measure.
Please alleviate this dilemma by returning driving instructors to work without delay.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557462

attributes.action: Support the Barbering, Hair and beauty sectors
attributes.background:
A large self employed sector that has been hit by covid and forgotten by government.
When people stop going out and work from him they cut back on our services . 
As a big self employed sector we have not been able to get funding and landlords still expect rent .
attributes.additional_details:
Help with wages 
Help with rent funding 
Don’t put us in the same group as bars : pubs Don’t close us down as we are a safe environment 

Don’t forget us

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

More financial support for Hair & Beauty sector: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554500

Do not require salons to close due to Covid-19: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/555408

Open barber shops and class barbers as key workers: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/312558

Keep the beauty industry open: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554478

attributes.action: Investigate systemic racism & inequalities within the prison service staff
attributes.background: There have been countless numbers of incidences & occurrences of systemic racism within the prison service staff towards inmates as well as other members of staff. This is unacceptable in this day & age, especially for a public sector that is based on reform, education & reintegration into community
attributes.additional_details: The government & parliament must investigate & take action before the issue of racism comes to a head and breaking point without the prison service staff. The government & parliament must use this to set an example & show that racism in any form & in any environment is completely unacceptable & will not be tolerated. The government & parliament has to make a stand with the BAME community and show it’s stance and strength towards racism; that any form of racism is a violation of human rights

rejection.details:
The Government-commissioned Lammy Review investigated the issue of structural racism in the criminal justice system, including the prison service.

Read more about the Lammy Review: https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/lammy-review.

While the Government has responded to the Review, some of its recommendations have not been acted upon. If you wish the findings of the Lammy Review to be acted upon, you may wish to sign this petition: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/329097. 

If you want an aspect of the prison service to be investigated which isn't covered by the Lammy Review, you could start a petition calling for such a review to be commissioned.

attributes.action: Temporarily ban the sale and use of disposable barbecues during lockdown
attributes.background: Countless warnings from fire services not to use disposable barbecues (and campfires) due to the risk of forest fires are being ignored. A local forest (Wareham, Dorset) has lost 220 hectares in a recent fire, taking over 150 firefighters to battle and there is an ongoing extreme fire risk.
attributes.additional_details:
As people begin to socialise with others outside but not at home, the use of these BBQs is likely to soar, posing an even greater risk to life and the environment and increasing strain on emergency services. 
Disposable barbecues are a well known danger, scorching the ground below during most uses and remaining hot for some time. Decimation of green areas by fire further accelerates climate change. This is in addition to their environmentally unfriendly single-use nature.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Change Environment Agency rules for part year registration
attributes.background: At present if you have a boat and it is on shore being worked on and you put it back in the river you have to pay a whole year's fee even if the boat is only in the water for 9 months.
attributes.additional_details: It seems inequitable to have to pay for something you haven't been able to use. You can get a refund on Car Tax if your vehicle is off the road. Why shouldn't that be the same for a river licence?

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase the PiCG (Plug in Car Grant) grant on electric vehicles
attributes.background: I would like the Government to raise the amount of the grant towards electric vehicles to help make them more accessible and to help boost the sales of such automobiles. Therefore, helping the environment and helping the government to reach its 2030 target.
attributes.additional_details: I believe that the Government grant and with its recent reduction is not enough to make electric vehicles accessible and affordable to most people. The grant comes into play when purchasing a new electric vehicle and means that there is an amount deducted from the total price. This is supposed to be to help make the electric vehicle transportation proposition more enticing to buyers and to make them more accessible to a wide range of people, but the current grant simply isn't doing enough.

attributes.action: I support Indian Government in Favour of Farm Reforms.
attributes.background: UK government should recognise that there are more people in support of farm reforms in India than there are against them.
attributes.additional_details: Show solidarity with democratic Indian government that is trying to bring farm reforms in the best interest of Indian People and Environment.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. 
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Enact the socio-economic duty in the Equality Act and make EIAs mandatory
attributes.background: The socio-economic duty in the Equality Act should be enacted and Equality Impact Assessments made mandatory to help ensure that future generations, regardless of background, are fully and equally accounted for in government decision making relating to health, environment and wellbeing.
attributes.additional_details: This is particularly important where decisions have the potential to widen intergenerational inequality. Children are vulnerable to severe impacts from government decision making. They have no legal representation in process, and their future needs as citizens who deserve sustainable lives is poorly factored in. The coronavirus response, resulting educational disruption for those who can tolerate it least without adequate mitigation, and the failure to respond adequately to the climate crisis, demonstrate that something is wrong in how government accounts for and acts on equality issues.

attributes.action: Replace the Landfill Tax with a waste premium
attributes.background:
The 1996 introduction of Landfill Tax has had the unintended consequences of incentivising fly tipping.
 
We should replace Landfill Tax with a waste premium rewarding the delivery of separated waste at recycling, processing and storage centres.
attributes.additional_details:
Our countryside and cities are blighted with unsightly and often dangerous waste from fly tipping and general littering. Our local authorities are paying for ineffective cleaning up.
 
Placing a value on the delivery of sorted waste at designated recycling, processing and storage centres could help transform our environment, save our wildlife, keep us safe and save money.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Vaccinate teachers before they return back to Schools
attributes.background: The Government should mandate that teachers receive a Covid-19 vaccine before they are made to go back on the 8th of March.
attributes.additional_details: The Government clearly said when schools became a "Covid-19 Hotspot" making this a risky environment for teachers to be in. Schools being back will cause a teacher to become more acceptable to catching the virus as children are prime carries of Covid-19. Teachers are fundamental in our society as they provide future economic growth to students and provide a service to our country that is essential. They deserve to have the same protection as Key-Workers.

rejection.details:

attributes.action: Ban schools from setting compulsory homework until sixth form
attributes.background: Prevent primary and secondary schools setting compulsory homework (not including virtual learning which takes place during standard school hours) until students start their A level courses.
attributes.additional_details: Homework harms social equality because some children have more help and access to resources, and a better work environment, than others, which makes it an unfair comparison of their performance. It can also harm children's mental health. Also, children already spend a lot of time at school during the day, and this ought to be enough time to teach everything on the national curriculum - if it proves impossible, then the curriculum should be reduced, not children's free time and wellbeing.

attributes.action: Raise littering fines to encourage people to use the bins provided.
attributes.background: Raise the current littering fines to a substantial sum. This will make people think twice before throwing litter from car windows or not using the provided bins when out walking.
attributes.additional_details: To help the natural environment, help protect wildlife from pollution and to make the towns and countryside a more healthy and beeter place to be.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334297

attributes.action: Require companies to report on Environment, Social and Governance factors
attributes.background: The Government should amend Company Law to include provision for non-financial reporting by UK businesses, with mandatory reporting of Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) factors.
attributes.additional_details:
Greater monitoring and transparency is needed so that UK businesses are accountable for their impact on the environment, their contribution to their local communities, how they promote diversity and workforce wellbeing, how they are governed and how they conduct their business day-to-day.
 
Environmental impact of businesses should be top of the agenda for the future of this world.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Close pre-schools in line with school closures to protect staff and children
attributes.background: If schools are closed to prevent the spread of Covid, pre-schools must also be closed. Pre-schools are less safe than schools. The scientist on BBC breakfast today January 5th clearly stated that pre-schools are not a safe environment. The decision to keep them open is political only.
attributes.additional_details: Neither young children nor carers at pre-schools can effectively socially distance or wear masks. There is much face to face and hands on contact (changing nappies etc). Staff and their families are being placed at an unacceptable risk. Families of children attending are at risk. Pre-schools are not in a position to make this decision for themselves they must follow Government guidelines or lose funding / be unable to pay staff.

attributes.action: A plastic free day in all UK schools.
attributes.background: What I want the Government or Parliament to do is to legislate a plastic-free day all across UK schools and education centres.
attributes.additional_details:
My reasons are that
 A. Plastics are not good for life under the sea 
B. Plastics are dangerous and can choke any animal that mistakes it for food
C. Little animals can get stuck in them and 
D. One plastic-free day a month/year can make a huge difference to improving our environment.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about plastics, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. It sounds like you want to make it illegal for schools to use any products containing plastic for one day a year, but it's not clear how this would work in practice.
                
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Establish a national waste plastic collection/recycling programme for England: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/553651

Introduce a levy on single-use disposable plastic: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554035

Heavy tax and public awareness on all 'Not Yet Recycled' plastics: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/315755

Reduced VAT on plastic-free products: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552824

Impose a levy on all plastic production in the UK: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/555701

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to fund a public awareness programme for schools on plastics, if that's something you would like to happen.

attributes.action:
Look into a policy for care homes during COVID 
So we visit.
attributes.background: Look into making a change to care home procedures during COVID so we can visit family in a safe environment

rejection.details:
The Government published guidance on 4th November to support safe home care visits under the national restrictions taking effect from 5th November:
https://www.gov.uk/government/news/new-guidance-to-support-safe-care-home-visits-during-lockdown

You could start a petition calling for specific changes to be made to this guidance, if there are specific changes you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Allow UK Tattoo Studios to Re-open
attributes.background: Tattoo studios and theIt staff are trained in the appropriate measures and actions to control and prevent cross contamination. A tattoo studio is one of the most sterile and hygienic business environments and requires more use of PPE than any of the other aforementioned businesses
attributes.additional_details:
Barbershops and Hairdressers use hairdryers and other air pressure based equipment, which has been banned due to it contributing to the spread of Coronavirus as it is airborne. 
Tattooists deal with open wounds which are cleaned regularly, leaving our clients at no extra risk of exposure to the RESPIRATORY not BLOODBORNE viris.
A tattoo studio will have far less people present at any one time, than the number of clients that come in and out of a barbers, hairdressers, restaurant or pubs.

rejection.details:
We have already published this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/320507

The Government has published guidance for people who provide close contact services, including hairdressers, barbers, beauticians, tattooists, sports and massage therapists, dress fitters, tailors and fashion designers: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/working-safely-during-coronavirus-covid-19/close-contact-services

attributes.action: Raise the minimum wage for social care employees and cleaners to a Living Wage.
attributes.background: I would like the Government to raise the minimum wage for social care employees and cleaners to a Living Wage.
attributes.additional_details:
People that work as social care providers or cleaners are among the lowest paid people in this country and I believe that whilst all jobs are important, cleaning and social care are, as current circumstances show, particularly important.

For those that aren't cleaning so that we live in a pleasant and healthy environment, there are those that are caring for us at every step in our lives.  

For them to be paid a penny less than a Living Wage is a national disgrace; I am hoping to change that.

rejection.details:
The Government is not responsible for setting the salary of most key workers, or setting minimum wages for particular sectors, but you may wish to sign petitions calling for the following actions:

Make hazard pay mandatory for key workers in the midst of COVID 19: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/307619

Give all key workers a 100% tax and Nat. Ins. holiday through COVID-19 crisis: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/306845

Pay bonus to all key workers: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/307215

Make the minimum wage equal for all ages and increase to at least £10: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/301749

Read correspondence with Government Ministers asking further questions: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/publications/3/correspondence/

attributes.action: Legalize wearing body cams for staff working in Emergency Departments
attributes.background:
Legalize healthcare staff working in unsafe environments like Emergency Departments to wear body cams for their protection and evidence.
Health care professionals in the ED are in a high pressure work environment and often get assaulted by patients/families or visitors verbally or physically
attributes.additional_details:
As health professsionals working in a volatile environment, we are subjected to a wide variety of risks, including violence from patients, family members or visitors
It is often difficult to establish the events due to lack of evidence and the existing cctv cameras donot cover most areas and have blind spots.
Allowing staff in the ED to wear body cams would empower them and reduce the incidences of violence and also serve as evidence for future investigations

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about protection of healthcare workers, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. It isn't illegal for healthcare workers to wear body cameras, and the Government has piloted rolling out body cameras to paramedics: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/paramedics-to-be-given-body-cameras-to-protect-them-from-abuse

If you want the Government to rollout body cameras to all healthcare workers, we could accept a petition requesting that.

attributes.action: Extend courses at Drama schools without extra fees due to lost time from COVID
attributes.background: I am asking for drama schools to have to extend courses (which are currently running) after coronavirus and social distancing has finished. This would be without extra fees, as online learning does NOT prepare or train actors for a working environment.
attributes.additional_details: Allow drama schools to continue our course after lockdowns and post COVID without extra charges. Potentially even postponing future class auditions and finish our teaching, students who have already paid, until our training is complete to the standard we were expecting and signed up for. Please note my school charge £11k a year and we are certainly not getting the full potential of this.

rejection.details:
Decisions about extending courses or providing additional free education as a result of disruption caused by Covid-19 is a matter for individual schools, not the Government or House of Commons.

If you are unhappy with the arrangements your school has put in place during the pandemic you should complain directly to your school.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to reimburse students for all fees for schools such as drama schools, where teaching has been particularly affected by the Covid-19 outbreak, if that's something you want to happen.

attributes.action: For IGCSE exams sat in the UK to be cancelled
attributes.background: To cancel the IGCSE exams for students originally sitting it in the United Kingdom due to the inconsistency between the gap of GCSE exam and IGCSE exam students, to make it a fair playing ground this year.
attributes.additional_details: We, as students taking IGCSE exams in the UK, would appreciate it if they were cancelled just like the GCSE exams, because of the simple reason that students taking any type of exam regardless have had the exact same journey of such trials and tribulations throughout the past year. It would only be fair if both were cancelled following the government’s choice of just GCSEs, as, again, doing the IGCSE exams does not mean we would’ve had any better environment to foster these grades, remembering we are all plagued with the same pandemic.

rejection.details:
Decisions about courses and assessments that are delivered by independent educational institutions, as opposed to state schools, are a matter for individual exam boards and educational institutions, not the Government or House of Commons.

We could accept a petition calling for the Government to prohibit any exams from taking place during the Covid-19 outbreak, if that is something you want to happen.

We understand that the current situation is stressful for many people, including students. Student Minds, a mental health charity for students, is collating guidance and developing resources to support students experiencing stress as a result of the current situation, which you may find useful: https://www.studentminds.org.uk/coronavirus.html

attributes.action: ALLOW RESITTING STUDENTS FROM 2020 TO RECEIVE UCAS PREDICTED GRADES THIS YEAR
attributes.background: Students resitting their A-level subjects from last year should be allowed to receive their UCAS predicted grades as their final grades this year as CAG's may be inaccurate due to how these students haven't been in a school environment in 10 months or more.
attributes.additional_details: Students last year were given the option to sit their A-levels in the summer of 2021 to increase their grades if they didn't feel prepared for the autumn series. With the latest development of summer exams being cancelled and replaced with CAG's, these students are at a disadvantage unless they can have their UCAS predicted grades, which are what their university offers are based on. This would allow them to have a better chance of getting into university this year.

rejection.details: The Education Secretary has said that this year the Government will "put our trust in teachers rather than algorithms": https://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/2021-01-06/debates/D2A64DD9-6A6B-4EAB-8001-C3BACDE25B02/Covid-19EducationalSettings

award some sort of funding to the grassroots of boxing like many other sports have been given 
With out funding clubs will close 
Kids on streets only means 1 thing crime
attributes.additional_details:
with out any sort of funding grassroots boxing could be finished 
We are not just boxing club but lifeline for kids to go to a safe environment 
Most youth clubs have been shut years ago boxing club provide a safe environment for young males and female to go guving them life skill keeping them out of gangs and crimes 
We need funding like the rest of sport as with out many gym will shut putting kids on the streets witch will result in crime rates going up Fact

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/561180

attributes.action: Allow grassroots football during the lockdown.
attributes.background: Children were deeply effected emotionally and physically when football was suspended during the first lockdown. Getting back to it provided a massive boost and to suspend it again will be a huge blow.
attributes.additional_details: If children are allowed to go to school where let’s be honest, the majority of viruses like coronavirus are spread, then it doesn’t seem to make any sense to prevent them from playing football outdoors in a safe environment. Teams, coaches, parents and children alike have proved that they can abide by the rules and there doesn’t appear to be any evidence to suggest that organised sport has contributed to the spike. Sport is good for children’s social, physical and mental well-being.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557169

attributes.action: For tattoos and piercings to be accepted in a formal working environment.
attributes.background: For tattoos to be accepted and allowed in a work environment as long as they do not contain inappropriate or explicit content. E.g. teachers being able to have a floral tattoo on show. Many people in professional jobs can still be fired due to this. When it is common in society and is an art form
attributes.additional_details: It is a freedom of expression and art. As long as it’s not inappropriate how is it any different to wearing a floral dress versus a spotty one. It does not in anyway affect professional. It’s the 21st century and it’s extremely common. It should not be a factor that can affect job dismissal.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/556422

attributes.action: Create a Northern Parliament
attributes.background: We wish for the creation of a Government separate from parliament. Made up of all elected members of the Northern Parliament (MNPs) and will be a law making body managing the economy, education, health, justice, rural affairs, housing, environment, transport, taxation and other matters
attributes.additional_details: We believe that the South has always culturally and economically separate from the North and has not for many years had the Norths best interests in mind as a result neglecting the people of the North and investment and development across much of the North. There for the Norths future is betty in Northern Hands

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/555283

attributes.action: Make single-use face masks biodegradable
attributes.background: Change the production of single-use face masks that are available to the general public to make them biodegradable.
attributes.additional_details: Too many facemasks are making their way into our oceans. Not only does this cause catastrophic issues for a wildlife and marine life, tiny microplastic particles make their way into food supply and contaminate human food produce. If even only 1 percent of single use masks were disposed of incorrectly, this would result in 10 million masks per month dispersed in the environment. The weight of each mask is about 4 grams, this results in more than 40 thousand kilograms of plastic in nature.

rejection.details:
The Government is not responsible for the production of face masks, this is a matter for individual producers.

We have accepted the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Ban the sale of disposable face masks to the general public: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549832

Ban the use of disposable face masks and plastic gloves in public places: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/324857

attributes.action: Stop local councils from privatising waste collection
attributes.background: The Government should stop local councils from privatising waste collection. This action by councils delegates their responsibility to create a clean and healthy environment for residents to private service providers who can profit at the expense of tax payers.
attributes.additional_details: Tax payers’ money shouldn’t be used to enrich private waste management companies, who are reported to make billions of pounds in revenue every year. According to the Office for National Statistics, waste management companies’ spending comes to just under £9.4 billion year.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create a police enforcement unit to deal with bus, tram and station crime.
attributes.background: Specialised policing doesn't exist for bus/tram crew and the stations from which they operate. This void leads to a lack of understanding from the police around what happens in this public transport environment up to & including dealing with serious offences.
attributes.additional_details:
I worked as a Customer Service Officer at a large public transport interchange for seven years and saw how the local police struggled to manage the constant stream of incidents we reported to them.  This led to a heavy drain on their resources in a time before austerity.

Such a large, constant and daily ask for policing resources sometimes led to a difficult relationship between the interchange and the police.  

We had genuine calls for service and they had no resources to respond.

We need to get the police to mirror British Transport Police (BTP) who currently police the railways.  BTP have an excellent record on dealing with criminal offences in the rail station/train environment - lets replicate that with bus/tram stations and the people who work in the industry.

attributes.action: Stop bonfires in residential areas before 10.30pm
attributes.background: Bonfires within residential areas are becoming more of an issue. The local authority advise against them but have no powers to stop them if they are controlled.
attributes.additional_details: This has been an issue for many years within local communities. However since the covid19 pandemic local councils have been unable to collect garden waste and household waste recycling centres have not been open as often. This is only causing an issue for local residents and polluting the environment.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310468

attributes.action: Ban alcohol sales in the UK during the pandemic.
attributes.background: Ban alcohol sales in supermarkets and corner shops during this pandemic. They should only be used to supply necessities during this crisis.
attributes.additional_details: While individuals are being made to stay at home, work from home and study at home, we should try to help those who are at home with parents/family members who are addicted to alcohol. Many children found school as their safe place, an escape, and now they don’t have this. We should try to protect those by ensuring they have a stable environment to concentrate in. Ensuring their mental health is not affected by those addicted by alcohol on a daily basis while this lockdown continues.

attributes.action: Solve Covid-19 crisis with mass voluntary infection of citizens not at risk.
attributes.background: Enable non-vulnerable citizens to volunteer to be infected with Covid-19 en masse in controlled environments, such as a universities and hotels. Once recovered and immune, they can be certified as safe to return to normal work and tend the vulnerable, helping the economy and society recover.
attributes.additional_details: Lockdown strategies are crippling economies with no clear end. Most people under 60 will only get mild symptoms and recover quickly. We need large numbers immune as soon as possible, so they can return to work and tend the vulnerable without infecting others, and to help create herd immunity quickly. Hotels, cruise ships and universities can house large volunteer groups in 4 weekly cycles. Volunteers certified as immune would be highly employable and help us fight and win this war.

rejection.details:
The medical response to coronavirus is an operational matter for the NHS, not the Government or Parliament.

You could start a new petition calling for the Government to end the lockdown for certain people, if that is something you would like to see.

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

NHS website: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/
UK Government website: https://www.gov.uk/coronavirus

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

attributes.action: Seek to rejoin the European Environment Agency
attributes.background: We want the Government to seek to rejoin the European Environment Agency (EEA), so that up to date UK environmental information is published alongside that of EU nations, in a clear, transparent and responsible way.
attributes.additional_details:
EEA environmental data no longer covers the UK, and we believe this has resulted in a reduction in the accessibility of transparent environmental information relating to the UK.
 
We believe the UK's membership of the EEA would mean better access to up to date UK environmental information, which is needed so the public can see how bad the climate and environmental situation is regarding pollution and the spread of various organisms throughout Europe, for example anopheles mosquitoes.

attributes.action: Care Homes should keep privately funded clients when their money runs out.
attributes.background: I want  legislation to enforce that Care Homes that have privately funded clients that have lived in there for more than (eg 1 year) to commit to keep them when their private funds run out at council rates.
attributes.additional_details: Because privately funded clients use up all their savings and sell their homes to live in a Care Home at great cost & if after living there for years all their money has been used and they require council funding, the homes often don’t accept council rates and the person has to be moved to another home. It is not fair! There should be legislation that prevents this from happening. Elderly people suffer and become disoriented when moved. They should remain in an environment they are settled in.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about charges for private care homes are a matter for care home providers, not the UK Government or Parliament.

attributes.action: Keep the right to educate otherwise through homeschooling
attributes.background: Currently, parents whose children are not thriving in the classroom environment have the legal right to 'educate otherwise', providing a personalised learning environment which has a higher-than-average success-rate. Caring parents must not be robbed of the right to support their child's education.
attributes.additional_details: Many children do not benefit from the state education system, and this affects them educationally, emotionally and professionally for the rest of their lives. Increased politicisation of the state education system often results in children being exposed to harmful and bizarre ideologies which have a corrupting and damaging effect on them. Home-schooling has also been found to be beneficial both to children who need extra individual attention, those who suffer bullying, and to gifted children.

rejection.details:
We understand you're concerned about parents' right to home-school their children, however there is no indication that the Government intends to remove this right unilaterally.

You might like to sign the following petition, which calls for certain provisions in the Schools Bill relating to home educated children to be removed:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/617340

Alternatively, you could start a new petition calling for certain provisions you are concerned about to be removed from the Bill, if they are different to the provisions mentioned in the petition above.

attributes.action: Fund local authorities to refurbish skate parks
attributes.background: The Government should provide local authorities with funding to refurbish skate parks in their area. This could create a positive environment for the community, including teenagers, that is inclusive for everyone and opens more people to hobbies/skills.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Review and reform the Display Screen Equipment regulations
attributes.background: The Government should review the Health and Safety (Display Screen Equipment) Regulations 1992 and consider reforms to explicitly reflect modern technology including laptops, mobile phones and tablets, and increased working from home.
attributes.additional_details:
We have internet access in most homes. We have hybrid and home working. We have laptops, tablets and mobile phones regularly in use for work. But workers using technology today are only protected by regulations that are almost 30 years old.

We believe that current Display Screen Equipment regulations do not adequately reflect modern work practices, or ensure employers take responsibility for providing adequate work environments, irrespective of where an employee is working, or the device they are using.

attributes.action: Remove biodiversity net gain mandate from the Environment Bill
attributes.background: The Government must remove the biodiversity net gain requirement from the Environment Bill, as this merely attempts to ‘incentivise’ developers to avoid the ‘most biodiverse’ sites, meaning they could build on already well-established biodiverse land in the absence of stronger protections.
attributes.additional_details:
You surely cannot re-establish an environment, which has taken tens of thousands of years to develop, in a period of thirty years.

The biodiversity net gain mandate in the Environment Bill could do more damage to our biodiversity than good. I worry it puts far too much power in the hands of developers and not enough in the hands of the public.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Student Nurses working throughout COVID-19  should receive the gov £500 bonus.
attributes.background: Pay our student nurses who have been working 37.5 hours on placement in the healthcare environment & covid wards throughout the pandemic. They have received no financial reward or bursary and yet again are forgotten, they are the only healthcare worker not to receive the £500 bonus.
attributes.additional_details: I have recently finished my 3rd year of student nursing and await my first position as a registered nurse. My cohort and I have received no bursary, no payment throughout our 3 years on placements and throughout the pandemic. Again, we are reminded how little our efforts are appreciated, we have been informed that we are not entitled to the government £500 bonus. We will soon start as RN’s in April and will be the only ones amongst our colleagues to have not received the bonus for our efforts

rejection.details:
Decisions relating to pay and bonuses for healthcare workers in Wales are a matter for the Welsh Government, not the UK Government. 

You could start a petition to the Welsh Parliament calling for the bonus being paid to healthcare workers in Wales to be extended to student nurses, if that is something you'd like to do. You can find out more about how to do this here: https://petitions.senedd.wales/.

attributes.action: We want a re-evaluation of the current education system
attributes.background: Our education system needs to be reformed to place creativity, invention and independent thinking at the heart of schooling, rather than memory and repetition based learning.
attributes.additional_details: Schools no longer prepare young people to enter a workplace which increasingly values the ability to think outside the box. Instead of equipping them with these vital skills, memory based assessments and evaluation based on repetition are what is valued most. Future generations need a learning environment that focuses on developing curiosity and learning from mistakes, rather than a one-size-fits-all mindset. Children need preparation to succeed in a future they are going to build.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see changes to the education system, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

The national curriculum already includes aims related to creativity and independent working, and it's not clear how you want the current education system to be re-evaluated or changed.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Award all NHS services a justified bonus and pay award, as Scotland has done.
attributes.background: Truly visit Covid ward,  ITU environment, watch the hard work staff do to help someone live, see people lose lives, see them work long hours, not just look after their drug needs, wash them, clean them after messing themselves, put cream on, talk, care for them.  Give A bonus, pay award we deserve.
attributes.additional_details: All the thanks in the world for all the NHS has done through Corona virus, and onwards means nothing when the government refuses them a justified bonus, and reasonable pay increase this year. Scotland at least payed a bonus. Boris Johnson took a IT bed, then says he cannot thank the NHS enough, but then does nothing, he and MP's will take a pay award, probably a big one based on how hard they have worked, NHS has always worked hard and then this government let's the NHS down again.

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

To pay every NHS and Social Care Worker in England a £500 "Thank You" Bonus: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/562495

Pay 15% bonus to public facing NHS staff: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/570762

Pay NHS staff a one-off bonus that recognises their efforts to combat covid: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/578308

attributes.action: Set minimum working temperature requirements in law for all workplaces
attributes.background: The Government should set minimum working temperatures of all workplaces in law. As it currently stands a Code of Practice produced by HSE says that they should be a certain temperature, but I believe that there should be a legal minimum temperature of 16 degrees or over for all workplaces.
attributes.additional_details: I’ve worked for 3 years now in a warehouse that isn’t heated and we as workers have to wear a large amount of layers to stay warm and it’s hard to work with your hands when they have no sensation in them. I believe workplaces should be required to heat these kinds of environments.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Shut all secondary schools down in England
attributes.background: Shut down all secondary schools in England due to increasing Covid-19 cases and children being in danger. School environments are not safe and practical for students at the moment, so that’s why they should have a break until everything gets back on track.
attributes.additional_details: This break could be until the new approved Covid vaccine is out and ready for use. Schools should invest in remote learning for the benefit of their students.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Close schools with confirmed COVID cases
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/551681

Reclose schools and colleges due to increase in COVID-19 cases
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550846

Require schools to support home learning during Covid-19 outbreak
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334065

attributes.action: Protect Langstone from flooding but NO to a wall by Royal Oak or wood boardwalks
attributes.background: We would like Government to request that Havant Borough Council via its subsidiary ESCP, do not build a flood wall around the Royal Oak, and instead look at alternative viable proposals that have been suggested.
attributes.additional_details:
Langstone is a picturesque waterfront village, keen to retain heritage & have flood defences.
In building a wall around a waterfront pub, there is risk that a beautiful old Pub could lose trade.
A wooden boardwalk is also proposed over a flag stoned path, this would be totally out of keeping with the environment, have short life span due to sea damage, and be dangerously slippery.
Help stop a wall around the Pub, stop a wooden path & ensure West Langstone is also defended with a flood plan.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for the local council.

attributes.action: Include NHS Ambulance & Nursing staff in payrises granted by the Chancellor 21/7
attributes.background: The government recently announced payrises to be granted to public sector staff-up to 3.1%.This covers NHS medical staff such as Doctors,Dentists,and Emergency Service workers such as Police,but has omitted Nurses and the Ambulance Service,who are on the front line & past rises haven’t met inflation
attributes.additional_details: The Ambulance Service &Nurses must be included in rises,given their role looking after our nation on the front line.Some staff have lived apart from their family to protect them whilst they fight Covid-19 at the forefront,many working additional hours under stressful circumstances and in difficult environments,some have even lost their lives to this virus.They are a key part of our public services and deserve equal treatment. Past rises have purely covered previous years where NO rise was given.

rejection.details:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/316307
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/313488
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300073

attributes.action: Cancel 2021 A-Level exams, with students still completing the course content
attributes.background: It is difficult to assume that all students have learned this content in the same environment and with the same resources. Given this, exam results would be unfair and unreliable. Undue stress and pressure put on students due to under confidence in their knowledge will be reflected in their grades.
attributes.additional_details: This needs to be taken seriously as poor grades will impede on our future. Evidence suggests that it is harder to recall information in a place dissimilar to where you learned it. This situation is incomparable to any other generation. It is still a priority to learn content for further education - that is if we are accepted with the grades we achieve due to these circumstances. Students will have to put in double the amount of effort for their grades to possibly not reflect their true potential

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/326066

attributes.action: Allow garden centres to reopen.
attributes.background: For many people their garden is their daily outdoor exercise. It is healthy for the mind and body. If people are tending the garden they are also less likely to be away from their home and this helps increase social distancing.
attributes.additional_details: If garden centres and nurseries apply the same controlled environment as supermarkets the benefits of them being open should outweigh any small additional risks. There are millions of pounds of plants ready to sell. Sales of these will be a boost to our hard pressed economy.

rejection.details:
Since you started your petition the Government has added garden centres and plant nurseries to the list of businesses that are permitted to open: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/further-businesses-and-premises-to-close/further-businesses-and-premises-to-close-guidance

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
 
Find out more and watch the Committee put questions suggested by petitioners to Government Ministers and the Deputy Chief Medical Officer: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/news/145767/committee-question-deputy-chief-medical-officer-and-ministers-on-coronavirus-response/
 
Read letters asking further questions of Government Ministers: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/publications/3/correspondence/

attributes.action: Temporarily relax the rules around school absences during the COVID19 outbreak
attributes.background: Allow parents to voluntarily remove their children from school without penalty during the current COVID19 outbreak, in order that they can avoid individual infection as well as protect siblings, parents and other, possibly vulnerable, family and community members from onward virus transmission.
attributes.additional_details:
Transmission of infectious diseases in schools is well documented. Due to different resource circumstances, schools provide varying degrees of 'safe environments' for children at this time.
Parents with alternative childcare/home school options should be encouraged to avoid the additional risk that attending school represents for infection of their child(ren), as well as for onward transfer of COVID19 to other - possibly vulnerable - members of the family and other members of the community.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300399
